author: By Tish Harrison Warren
title: ‘Why Does God Keep Making Poets?’
description: Since ancient times, poetry has been our way of paying attention to the world and our place in it.
content: In the heat of the summer, this slow curve of the midyear, I find myself wanting to pause and catch my breath. As many people take summer vacations or simply enjoy a cold drink on their porch, it is a good time to take up new kinds of reading. I have written before about why I think poetry is crucial now, and I asked my former poetry teacher, Abram Van Engen, if he’d speak to us about how to read poetry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. Airs Bigoted New Covid Conspiracy Theory About Jews and Chinese
description: The long-shot candidate for the Democratic presidential nomination has a history of embracing conspiracy theories. His latest comments claimed the virus spared certain ethnic and religious groups.
content: A conspiracy-filled rant by Robert F. Kennedy Jr. that the Covid-19 virus was engineered to spare Ashkenazi Jews and Chinese people has stirred accusations of antisemitism and racism in the Democratic candidate’s long-shot run for president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: In Florida, Trump Says DeSantis Has No Path to Victory
description: Former President Donald J. Trump taunted Gov. Ron DeSantis, his chief Republican rival, for his absence from the conservative Turning Point Action Conference.
content: On the home turf of his chief Republican rival and in his adopted state, former President Donald J. Trump told a sprawling conservative gathering in Florida on Saturday night that it was futile for Gov. Ron DeSantis to keep battling him for the party’s presidential nomination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ella Braidwood
title: ‘Everyone Expects Us to Win’: England Tries to Live in the Now
description: Injuries weakened the Lionesses, and recent results have raised eyebrows. But the players and their coach say it takes a lot to shake a champion.
content: Sarina Wiegman likes to look on the bright side of things. In April, England’s 30-match unbeaten run was ended with a 2-0 loss to Australia. But Wiegman, the team’s Dutch coach, deliberately focused on the positives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Sally Kempton, Rising Star Journalist Turned Swami, Dies at 80
description: She was making her name in New York journalism in the footsteps of her famous father and becoming an outspoken feminist when she met an Indian guru.
content: Sally Kempton, who was once a rising star in the New York journalism world and a fierce exponent of radical feminism, but who later pivoted to a life of Eastern asceticism and spiritual practice, died on Monday at her home in Carmel, Calif. She was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: A Fruit Salad That Isn’t Sad
description: Tossing summer melons and berries with lime juice — and some sugar that’s been massaged with the zest — makes for a salad that’s delightful, not depressing.
content: Good morning. When you run into a fruit salad in the wild, it’s generally trash: unripe shards of cantaloupe mixed with cardboard honeydew, pale strawberry halves, slippery rounds of browned banana, fibrous hunks of pineapple, gritty blueberries, the occasional squishy grape. It’s depressing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: ‘The Bear’ and the Need for a Place to Belong
description: The powerful moral message of FX’s hit show.
content: Every now and then, a fictional character can have a profound real-world impact. I’m thinking, for example, of Jason Sudeikis’s Ted Lasso in 2020. There was a moment in the first season of the character’s self-titled show when a simple act of immediate forgiveness symbolized the generosity of a show that radiated across American culture and reminded us of the power of kindness and mercy to alter the course of a person’s life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morgan Campbell
title: Heralded Cuban Wins in an Unusual Introduction to Pro Boxing
description: Decorated as an amateur, Andy Cruz had an unusual entrance into the pros, fighting for more rounds than typical for a first-timer. Afterward, he had an eye on what could be next.
content: Andy Cruz toted his new title belt while he hugged friends and saluted his followers on Instagram Live. When he and his team gathered for a photo, Derek Ennis, the head trainer, draped his right arm over one of Cruz’s shoulders. Everyone else stared at the camera; Cruz’s attention was elsewhere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Biden’s ‘Final’ Order on Kennedy Files Leaves Some Still Wanting More
description: The president has finished a review first mandated by law in 1992, and while a vast majority of papers related to the assassination of President John F. Kennedy have been released, some remain redacted.
content: On June 22, 1962, an intelligence official drafted a memo summarizing a letter intercepted between Lee Harvey Oswald and his mother. The memo was made public long ago. But for 60 years, the name of the letter opener was kept secret.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien and Reid J. Epstein
title: DeSantis Burns Cash, and Pence Struggles: 5 Takeaways From 2024 Filings
description: Warning signs for Ron DeSantis were among the biggest developments of the latest campaign filings, which created a fuller financial picture of the 2024 field.
content: As a fuller financial picture of the 2024 presidential race emerged with Saturday’s campaign filing deadline, trouble appeared to lurk below the surface for Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: Over 700 Civil War-Era Gold Coins Found Buried on a Kentucky Farm
description: “This is the most insane thing ever,” said the man who unearthed the coins in a cornfield, according to a video posted last month.
content: A Civil War-era treasure of more than 700 gold coins was unearthed in a Kentucky cornfield, a find that has at least partly vindicated legends of lost Civil War gold that have driven American treasure hunters for more than 150 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Sharansky Danziger
title: My Brave, Brilliant Friend Was Kidnapped in Iraq. Will the World Stand Up for Her?
description: Elizabeth Tsurkov, the Russian-Israeli researcher who has been kidnapped in Iraq, took risks in pursuit of knowledge, understanding and doing what she felt was right.
content: It’s a beautiful summer day at my in-laws’ house in Los Angeles. The sun is out. My kids are playing on the grass with their grandparents, a rare treat since we live in Jerusalem. But I can’t enjoy it. One of my oldest friends, Liza — Elizabeth Tsurkov — is being held by a militia in Iraq, and I’m terrified.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: Detroit Takes On Problems That Were Once Beyond Reach
description: Ten years after becoming the largest American city to file for bankruptcy, Detroit is stepping up code enforcement and sprucing up parks. The new moment carries risks, too.
content: On a stretch of Detroit’s West Side with mostly empty storefronts, the building with “Fried Fish” painted on its window had not served a meal in years. A small forest had sprouted in the alley. Plywood patched holes in the back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Wang
title: Biden Is Beating China on Chips. It May Not Be Enough.
description: The Biden administration, in its zeal to keep advanced chips away from China, is failing to miss the risks in many other sectors.
content: The White House is intent on outcompeting China on technology. The ground on which this competition is taking place is chip making. But the Biden administration shouldn’t sit back and savor this accomplishment for one reason: What if its core belief — that advanced semiconductors are one of the critical fronts in the contest — is wrong?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: ‘Mission: Impossible’ for Tom Cruise: Meeting Hollywood Expectations
description: The seventh film in the 27-year-old movie franchise was No. 1 at the box office, taking in $80 million over its first five days. But the movie industry was hoping for more.
content: Tom Cruise’s seventh “Mission: Impossible” spectacle, which arrived in theaters on Wednesday and cost at least $400 million to make and market, was supposed to mark a turning point at the troubled summer box office. Death-defying stunts! A new love interest! That thrilling theme song!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eyal Press, Adrienne Hurst, Aaron Esposito, John Woo, Dan Farrell and Alec Redfearn
title: The Sunday Read: ‘The Moral Crisis of America’s Doctors’
description: The corporatization of health care has changed the practice of medicine, causing many physicians to feel alienated from their work.
content: Some years ago, a psychiatrist named Wendy Dean read an article about a physician who died by suicide. Such deaths were distressingly common, she discovered. The suicide rate among doctors appeared to be even higher than the rate among active military members, a notion that startled Dean, who was then working as an administrator at a U.S. Army medical research center in Maryland. Dean started asking the physicians she knew how they felt about their jobs, and many of them confided that they were struggling. Some complained that they didn’t have enough time to talk to their patients because they were too busy filling out electronic medical records. Others bemoaned having to fight with insurers about whether a person with a serious illness would be preapproved for medication.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christoph Koettl
title: Satellite Images of Belarusian Base Suggest Wagner’s Possible Arrival
description: More than a dozen vehicles have arrived at a rapidly built military field camp in Belarus, and video from Russia showed a convoy flying Wagner flags on the move.
content: Satellite images, analyzed by The New York Times, showed increased activity this weekend at a military field camp in Belarus, including the arrival of vehicles that resemble those used by the Russian mercenary group Wagner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut and Alex Traub
title: Jane Birkin, Singer, Actress and Fashion Inspiration, Dies at 76
description: She was a lithe beauty of 1960s European film, a famous musical collaborator and lover of Serge Gainsbourg, and the namesake of elegant Hermès handbags.
content: Jane Birkin, who helped define chic female sexuality of the 1970s as an actress in arty and erotic European movies and in her relationship — equal parts romantic and artistic — with the singer Serge Gainsbourg, died on Sunday in Paris. Ms. Birkin, who later became known for inspiring one of the best known lines of luxury handbags, was 76.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anthony Ham
title: Fossils Where They Don’t Belong? Maybe We Just Didn’t Look Hard Enough.
description: Researchers are fiercely debating whether claims about the origins of mammals result from a bias toward Northern Hemisphere fossil sites.
content: In 1996, paleontologists made a startling discovery in northwestern Madagascar. Among dinosaur bones and sandy sediment there emerged a 167-million-year-old tiny jaw fragment with three teeth. It belonged to Ambondro mahabo, a species that was 25 million years older than any mammal of its kind ever found.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jaclyn Greenberg
title: How to Make Your Home Accessible
description: Tap into the resources available from states, nonprofits, developers and housing groups to make spaces work for families of all abilities.
content: Tatiana Martinez needed an accessible home. Her then 7-year-old son, who uses a wheelchair, was too heavy to carry upstairs to his second-floor bedroom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Wright-Piersanti
title: Remembering the Dead
description: Fans are saying goodbye, again, to the band that was once the Grateful Dead.
content: Fans of the Grateful Dead are saying goodbye to the band this weekend. It’s not the first time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: How the Hollywood Strikes Could Affect Fall Festivals and Oscar Season
description: Without stars on the red carpet, prestige titles like the Leonard Bernstein biopic “Maestro” and the Elvis Presley tale “Priscilla” may not get the push they need.
content: With summer movie season at its midpoint, Hollywood typically begins to turn its gaze toward the fall, when a trio of major film festivals acts as the unofficial kickoff to Oscar season. Seven of the last 10 best-picture winners had their debuts at a fall festival, coming out of the gate with standing ovations and critical acclaim that helped propel them through the monthslong awards-show gantlet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxane Gay
title: My Boss Made Me Post This
description: Your employer can put limits on what you put out on social media, but should not force you to spam your friends.
content: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Penn
title: A New Job for Electric Vehicles: Powering Homes During Blackouts
description: Some energy experts say battery-powered vehicles will increasingly help keep the lights on and support electric grids, rather than straining them.
content: In early March, strong winds brought down trees and power lines in the Nashville area, leaving thousands of homes without power. But about 20 miles outside the city an electric pickup truck fed energy to John and Rachelle Reigard’s home, keeping their lights on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabriela Garcia
title: A Sequel to Cristina García’s ‘Dreaming in Cuban,’ 30 Years On
description: “Vanishing Maps” returns to the del Pino family, now spread across three continents and four generations.
content: A halo representing a mother’s ghost appears in Cristina García’s “Vanishing Maps” as the Berlin drag queen La Ivanita — given name Ivanito Villaverde — prepares to perform Olga Guillot’s 1950s bolero “Miénteme,” in which the singer begs her paramour to lie to her, to keep the illusion of his love alive. Meanwhile, in Cuba, Ivanito’s nonagenarian grandmother Celia is surprised to discover even her doctor has left the country amid economic hardship on the island; as her granddaughter (and Ivanito’s cousin) Irina, living in Russia, romanticizes the time her parents met in Prague in 1968: “Hopes had been impossibly high then — for democracy, for freedom, even for love.” So opens this follow-up to García’s 1992 debut, “Dreaming in Cuban,” which traced the generational ruptures within one diasporic family from the 1930s to the 1980s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Lifelong Burden of a Chronic Illness
description: Responses to a photo series about treatment for multiple sclerosis. Also: An imperfect church; beyond the Ivy League; transgender rights; harassment of realtors.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy
title: In Phoenix, Firefighters Battle an Invisible Inferno
description: A two-week stretch of 110-degree days sends the fire department scrambling to rescue people overcome by heat, and tests a force already accustomed to tough summers.
content: Deirdre’s temperature was 104 degrees when the paramedics arrived on Saturday afternoon and started infusing ice-cold saline into her veins, racing to cool her before she became another victim of Phoenix’s merciless heat wave.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeré Longman and Linh Pham
title: Worlds Apart: Cup’s Expansion Brings the Games of a Lifetime
description: Vietnam, one of eight nations playing in its first Women’s World Cup, will face the U.S. this week. Its presence highlights the growth of women’s soccer, but also the challenges that remain.
content: When Vietnam fielded its first women’s national soccer team in 1997, its players wore oversized jerseys made for men. At times, the team had to travel an hour and a half from Ho Chi Minh City, formerly Saigon, to reach an available training site. Some players pushed carts on the street and sold bread to sustain their nascent playing careers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Michael Wines
title: Alabama Scrambles to Redraw Its Voting Map After a Supreme Court Surprise
description: State lawmakers have until Friday to come up with new congressional districts that do not illegally dilute the power of Black voters.
content: Under orders from the Supreme Court to produce a voting map that no longer illegally dilutes the power of Black voters in Alabama, the state’s lawmakers are now facing a high-stakes scramble to come up with an acceptable replacement by the end of this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: How Julie Ertz Got Her Game Back
description: Ertz, a two-time World Cup winner, knew she had to hustle to return to the national team after having a baby. A boys’ team offered a helping hand.
content: Even before Julie Ertz gave birth to her son, Madden, last August, she knew it would be a challenge to return to the fitness and form that would be required of her if she wanted to play in a third Women’s World Cup.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Penn
title: Pay to Rise as Much as 40% in Deal Reached by United and Pilots
description: The proposed four-year agreement would be worth $10 billion over the life of the contract.
content: United Airlines pilots reached agreement with the company on Saturday on a contract valued at $10 billion that would increase pay up to 40 percent over four years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Biden, With Sluggish Small Donations, Waits for Liberal Energy to Rise
description: Wealthy Democrats have thrown their money behind the president’s re-election bid, but for many reasons, the party’s small donors have yet to step up their contributions.
content: When President Biden traveled to San Francisco last month, he raised more than $10 million in 36 hours from wealthy Democrats. Trips to Chicago and New York netted millions more, as did fund-raising events around Washington, proving that the party’s big-donor class is fully committed to Mr. Biden’s re-election campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Vivek Shankar
title: Black Sea Grain Deal Hangs on 11th-Hour Talks, Again
description: Russia has repeatedly threatened to pull out of the wartime export agreement, which has helped stabilize global grain prices and avert famines. The latest deadline to renew it is Monday.
content: The United Nations on Sunday awaited a response from Russia on renewing a deal that allows Ukraine to export its grain amid a wartime blockade, a necessity in helping keep global food prices stable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By CJ Hauser
title: Water, Water, Everywhere, and Now Her Husband Is Gone
description: In Stephanie Bishop’s psychological thriller, “The Anniversary,” tragedy strikes on a cruise.
content: In love, in art, in crime, what is done intentionally and what is done unintentionally? This is the question at the core of Stephanie Bishop’s fourth novel, “The Anniversary.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: What’s Worse Than Heat and Humidity? Heat and Humidity on the Subway.
description: In most New York City subway cars, the air-conditioning works. But if you find yourself in a hot car, the journey can be excruciating. Just ask the riders of Car 1859.
content: You make a mad dash out of one subway car and into another before the doors slam shut. Or you use your hands as fans. Or you sit by an open window, hoping for even the slightest hint of a breeze. Or, resigned to your sweaty fate, you call out to fellow commuters, warning them not to step aboard: “It’s very hot!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Four Prisoners Test Positive as Covid-19 Re-emerges at Guantánamo Bay
description: One detainee with the coronavirus was charged in the destroyer Cole bombing, and another in the Sept. 11 attacks, both death penalty cases. A third was hospitalized for observation.
content: Four high-value prisoners at Guantánamo Bay have tested positive for the coronavirus, including one man who was moved to the base hospital for closer observation, according to people familiar with operations at the U.S. base in Cuba.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Flavelle
title: As Climate Shocks Multiply, Designers Seek Holy Grail: Disaster-Proof Homes
description: The homebuilding industry has been slow to adopt changes that can better protect against extreme weather. Some architects are showing what’s possible.
content: Jon duSaint, a retired software engineer, recently bought property near Bishop, Calif., in a rugged valley east of the Sierra Nevada. The area is at risk for wildfires, severe daytime heat and high winds — and also heavy winter snowfall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: We Are All Background Actors
description: Why should you care about the strikes in Hollywood? Because they are much more than a revolt of the privileged.
content: In Hollywood, the cool kids have joined the picket line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: A National Treasure, Tarnished: Can Britain Fix Its Health Service?
description: As it turns 75, the N.H.S., a proud symbol of Britain’s welfare state, is in the deepest crisis of its history.
content: Fifteen hours after she was taken out of an ambulance at Queen’s Hospital with chest pains and pneumonia, Marian Patten was still in the emergency room, waiting for a bed in a ward. Mrs. Patten, 78, was luckier than others who arrived at this teeming hospital, east of London: She had not yet been wheeled into a hallway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa J. Rubin
title: As Iraq Tries to Chill Critics, Its Newest Target Is Social Media
description: New regulations on “degrading content” are part of a broader campaign to silence independent voices.
content: In one social media clip, a young Iraqi woman dances at a national soccer tournament. In another, she dances at her son’s birthday party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: Jane Birkin: Decades of Effortless Elegance
description: The British-French singer, actress and style icon may have been known as the inspiration for the Birkin bag, but she was so much more.
content: There are few things more tedious than the term “fashion icon,” but that is not to suggest people don’t exist who definitively set styles for their time. Jane Birkin was one of them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Veronica Gillispie-Bell
title: More Mothers Are Dying. It Doesn’t Have to Be This Way.
description: No mother should ever go into childbirth fearful that the cost of bringing in a life will be the loss of her own.
content: After Tori Bowie, an elite athlete, died in May, the reality of the health risk to Black women posed by childbirth was once again in the spotlight. The maternal mortality rate for Black women in America is, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 2.6 times that for white women.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Netanyahu Released From Hospital After Undergoing Tests
description: The Israeli prime minister spent Saturday night in a hospital after feeling dizziness, but was said to be in “excellent condition” on Sunday.
content: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel was discharged from the hospital on Sunday in what medical officials described as “excellent condition,” after an overnight stay involving a series of tests and being fitted with an implanted heart monitor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Monday Briefing: U.S. and China Restart Climate Talks
description: Also, the G20 finance ministers prepare to meet in India, China targets Canadian politicians and cricket rises in Texas.
content: John Kerry, the U.S. climate envoy, arrived in Beijing yesterday to restart climate negotiations with China. Over three days of talks, he and Xie Zhenhua, his Chinese counterpart, will look for ways to collaborate, despite simmering tensions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Carlos Alcaraz Shows Novak Djokovic That His Championships Are Numbered
description: Djokovic had won the past three Grand Slams he played in to reach 23 major titles, but Alcaraz, Wimbledon’s newest singles champion, proved on Sunday he is not invincible.
content: With the driving force of a forehand winner, Novak Djokovic slammed his racket into a net post, then quickly picked up the twisted wreckage and sat down. It was an uncharacteristic outburst of rage from the 23-time Grand Slam singles champion, and it seemed to be about more than the point he had just lost.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Review: A ‘Semele’ Bound for New York Takes Its First Bows
description: Claus Guth’s entertaining and often sexy new staging of Handel’s opera-oratorio hybrid in Munich is a coproduction with the Metropolitan Opera.
content: Staging oratorios in the opera house is nearly routine nowadays, especially those by Handel; for every “Agrippina,” you’re likely to get a “Messiah” too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simbarashe Cha
title: Tennis Style, Anyone?
description: At Wimbledon, the off-court fashion included three-piece suits, smart-looking hats and lots of tennis whites.
content: If you spend any time around the All England Club during Wimbledon, as I did for several hours last Monday, you start to notice that many people dress in what could be described as starter kits: a lot of men wear button-down shirts and shorts, while women tend to opt for summer dresses or skirts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: Two Theories of What I’m Getting Wrong
description: Is it impossible for liberalism to build?
content: Two smart writers have written thoughtful pieces — one from the right, one from the left — explaining where I’ve gone terribly wrong.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Alcaraz Wins Wimbledon in a Thrilling Comeback Against Djokovic
description: Carlos Alcaraz won his first Wimbledon title and left Novak Djokovic, the overwhelming favorite, with his first finals loss at the All England Club in a decade.
content: After years of false starts, men’s tennis finally has a proper war between the generations.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘The Man Looked Familiar, but I Couldn’t Quite Place Him’
description: A Manhattan reunion, dinner at Mamma Leone’s and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: C.R. Roberts, Scoring Sensation in Milestone Game, Dies at 87
description: In 1956, he starred for the University of Southern California in a signal victory over an all-white University of Texas team after withstanding racial threats.
content: C.R. Roberts, a Black running back for the University of Southern California, was afraid of what might happen when his integrated Trojans football team traveled to the Jim Crow South to play the all-white University of Texas Longhorns in Austin in 1956.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: ‘We Must Go Faster’: Yellen Says Rich Nations Must Speed Debt Relief
description: Helping the world’s low-income countries will be a central topic as U.S. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen and other G20 finance ministers gather in India.
content: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen called on Sunday for international creditors to speed up their efforts to provide debt relief to developing countries facing default, arguing that shoring up their deteriorating finances would benefit the global economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Wartik
title: An Online Comments Section Where Everybody Knows Your Screen Name
description: Metropolitan Diary, a column that captures the serendipity of New York City life, provides a place for regulars to meet.
content: When Sivaram Pochiraju told a group of friends that he and his wife were having a difficult week, Janet Cathcart reassured him that the couple had the support of “a large extended family.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: DeSantis Sheds Staff Amid Heavy Spending
description: The dismissals come as his campaign for the Republican nomination for president struggles to gain traction against former President Donald J. Trump, who is leading in polls.
content: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida has started cutting campaign staff just months into his presidential bid, as he has struggled to gain traction in the Republican primary and lost ground in some public polls to former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Two Sports Connected by Squabbling
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, July 16, 2023.
content: “This would never go down at Coney Island. Somebody would just get shot.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Betts and Elise Young
title: Five Dead in Flash Flooding in Philadelphia Suburbs
description: Sudden, torrential rains struck areas in Bucks County, Pa., trapping people in their cars. Much of the Northeast was experiencing periods of heavy rainfall.
content: Fierce thunderstorms, heavy rainfall and flash flooding wreaked havoc across the Northeast over the weekend, killing five people in Pennsylvania, halting flights at major airports in the New York metropolitan area and downing power lines. In one part of Long Island, five inches of rain fell in less than two hours.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 16, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, July 16, 2023.
content: An article on Page 4 this weekend about a revival of the play “Orpheus Descending” misidentifies Erica Schmidt’s role in the making of the 2021 film “Cyrano.” She wrote the screenplay; she did not direct.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Jane Birkin: An Adventurous Artist Made in England, Forged in France
description: Birkin had a thriving career as a singer and an actress, in both communicating a seemingly nonchalant demeanor that camouflaged a melancholy core.
content: For most of her life, Jane Birkin, who died Sunday at 76, acted as a bridge — an elegant one, with an affectless grace that never betrayed the strains of load bearing. She connected her native Britain and her adopted France, two countries physically close but often at odds. She never lost her English accent when she spoke, somehow joining the two languages into her own Birkin-ese, “the improbable French that added to her charm,” as Le Monde put it. She floated among song, cinema and theater, and she could reach large, varied audiences while also connecting with France’s auteur culture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya King and Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: Senate Democrats Outpace Republicans in Fund-Raising in Key States
description: The 2024 election map is a challenging one for Democrats — especially in states they need to hold for a majority. But the incumbents made a strong financial showing this quarter.
content: Senate Democrats staring down tough re-election fights can look to one bright spot: sizable fund-raising hauls and cash stockpiles more than a year before Election Day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Man Who Crashed Into Teens After Doorbell Prank Gets Life in Prison
description: Anurag Chandra was convicted of first-degree murder and attempted murder in April after crashing his car into another vehicle, killing three teenagers and injuring three others.
content: A California man who crashed into a car of six teenagers after they played a doorbell prank on him in 2020 was sentenced to life in prison without the possibility of parole on Friday after his conviction on murder charges, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mya Guarnieri
title: Who Gets to Wear G-Strings Now?
description: More women are adopting the “less is more” philosophy.
content: Codi Maher noticed that bikini bottoms were shrinking a few years ago. “First it was cheeky cut, then Brazilian,” said Ms. Maher, a 30-year-old real estate agent in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. As the fabric covering women’s derrières disappeared, she started thinking about getting a thong swimsuit of her own: “I was just like, everyone’s wearing them, screw it, I don’t care.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Small, Hidden and Deadly: Mines Stymie Ukraine’s Counteroffensive
description: To gain ground, Ukrainian forces have to make their way through a variety and density of Russian land mines they never imagined.
content: It was a grisly scene of bloody limbs and crumpled vehicles as a series of Russian mines exploded across a field in southern Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Once, Once
description: Alexander Liebeskind is just checking in on us.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues | Solving Tip
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Diamond
title: Hot Trends, Hotter Temperatures
description: As dangerous heat waves spread across the United States, there is one word on many minds: hot.
content: “The summer of 2023 is shaping up to be a hot one,” two New York Times reporters wrote in June. They meant temperatures, not trends.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko and Erin Nolan
title: In Gilgo Beach Killings, an Arrest Bears Out a Decade-Old Prediction
description: In 2011, experts made a list of characteristics they predicted the suspect would have. The man charged in three of the killings checks many of those boxes.
content: In April 2011, just months after the bodies of four women were discovered buried near Gilgo Beach on Long Island’s South Shore, several experts and criminologists put together a sketch for The New York Times of the characteristics they expected to see in a suspect.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Leatherby
title: How a Vast Demographic Shift Will Reshape the World
description: The most powerful countries have benefited from large work forces for decades. What happens when they retire?
content: The most powerful countries have benefited from large work forces for decades. What happens when they retire?

title: Joyce Carol Oates Figured Out the Secret to Immortality
description: “Everything that you think is solid,” says the celebrated writer, “is actually fleeting and ephemeral.”
content: “Everything that you think is solid,” says the celebrated writer, “is actually fleeting and ephemeral.”
